title: Çelebi Ismail Pasha
text:
Çelebi Ismail Pasha (died November or December 1702) was an <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> statesman who held various administrative roles in his career as a high-level official in the Ottoman government.
He began his career as a soldier in the <a href="Janissary">Janissary</a> corps of the <a href="Ottoman%20army">Ottoman army</a>. He eventually became the <a href="Agha%20%28Ottoman%20Empire%29">agha</a> (head) of the Janissaries in July or August 1692, holding the position until the end of that year or the next year (1693). He was described as "tall and handsome" and could not read or write.
Ismail Pasha's was the Ottoman governor of:
As governor of Egypt.
One of the first things that Ismail Pasha did after he was appointed the <a href="List%20of%20Ottoman%20governors%20of%20Egypt">governor of Egypt</a> and had arrived in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a> in October 1695 was to reveal to the <a href="kaymakam">kaymakam</a> (acting governor) Ibrahim Bey, who had occupied the position until Ismail Pasha's arrival in Egypt, that the <a href="Sultan%20of%20the%20Ottoman%20Empire">sultan</a> <a href="Mustafa%20II">Mustafa II</a> had ordered him to close the deficit in the Egypt provincial treasury by whatever means possible. He accomplished this by assigning a local Hasan Bey to do the job, who managed to break even and even create a surplus in the treasury. He also settled the accounts of his predecessor as governor, <a href="Hazinedar%20Moral%C4%B1%20Ali%20Pasha">Hazinedar Moralı Ali Pasha</a>, and after he had paid them, allowed him to return to <a href="Istanbul">Constantinople</a>, the Ottoman capital.
Ismail Pasha had a "taqiya" (a worship building for <a href="dervish">dervish</a>es) built in the Kara Meydan square of the <a href="Cairo%20Citadel">Cairo Citadel</a>, from which Ottoman governors ruled. In 1696, he organized an elaborate and massive celebration and feast for his sons, who were just circumcised, that lasted for 15 days.
He was deposed by the local soldiers in September 1697, and the acting governor became <a href="Kesici%20Hasan%20Pasha">Kesici Hasan Pasha</a>. Ismail Pasha then headed an expedition to Baghdad. After this event, a local Arab source claims that the sultan then sent an order for Ismail Pasha's execution and that he defected to Persia to escape. However, another source, the 19th-century Ottoman Turkish historian Mehmet Süreyya Bey, claims that he became the Ottoman governor of Baghdad, and then of Van, and makes no mention of an execution order.
